Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will use data from the 10-year deployment of the seismic stations in the USArray Transportable Array across the lower 48 states to map seismological properties of the top 100 km of the crust and shallow mantle beneath the continent. The focus of the project is a comprehensive analysis of seismic surface waves using traditional and modern methods, including the analysis of ambient seismic noise, which are seismic waves caused by human activity, ocean waves, and atmospheric phenomena such as wind. The project will generate high-resolution maps of different properties of the rocks in the crust and mantle that will facilitate continent-wide interpretation of the structure and tectonic evolution of North America.

The seismic data collected by nearly 2000 sensors distributed across the continent will be used to determine (1) maps of short-period (5-40 sec) Love and Rayleigh wave speed using inter-station cross correlation of seismic noise; (2) maps of longer-period (25-125 sec) Love and Rayleigh wave speed using two-station and mini-array techniques; and (3) maps of local elastic Rayleigh wave amplification at longer periods using a differential-amplitude technique. Quantitative comparisons of the data with model-based predictions will be used to demonstrate the consistency between results of different researchers, and identify differences that motivate further investigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research was to complete the mapping of several seismic-wave-propagation characteristics across the conterminous US using data from the 10-year-long deployment of the USArray Transportable Array, a component of the EarthScope Project.
The primary outcomes of the research are several sets of maps representing the geographical variations in seismic properties that can be interpreted in terms of shallow and deep geological structure. Measurements were made on seismograms recorded on more than 1800 seismometers distributed across the US using signals generated by more than 2000 earthquakes as well as the continuous background noise signals associated with elastic waves caused by ocean waves. The earthquake signals were used to map propagation speeds of Love and Rayleigh waves at periods between 25 and 125 seconds, and to constrain the local amplification of such waves at the site of each seismic station. These velocities and amplification factors are useful for imaging the deeper structure of the continent, and inferring its geological history. The noise signals were used to map the variations in speed of Love and Rayleigh waves at shorter periods, 5-40 seconds. The short-period velocity variations reflect shallow structure, primarily the thickness and composition of the Earth's crust. The shortest-period waves are particularly slowed down by the existence of thick sedimentary layers. The accompanying figure shows phase velocity of Love waves at different periods. The 5-seconds map clearly maps the large basins in the west and the thick sediments along the Gulf Coast.
The data products generated by this research will be useful for further investigations of the structure of the North American continent.
